NZ Elections Explained

Source: vignettes/articles/nz-elections-explained.rmd
nz-elections-explained.rmd


NZ Electoral System

New Zealand has non-compulsory voting with voters electing 120 members to a unicameral House of Representatives using a mixed-member proportional (MMP) voting system. Under this system:

  • 72 members are elected from single-member electorates (Electorate MPs) using first-past-the-post (FPTP) voting.
    • 7 of these seats are Māori electorates which are reserved for people of Māori ethnicity or ancestry who choose to place themselves on a separate electoral roll. Both Māori and General electorates overlap.
  • 48 members are elected from nationwide, closed (i.e., the order of the candidates is determined by individual parties), party lists (List MPs). There is no separation between Māori and General electoral roll voters for List MPs.

This means that voters cast two votes on election day: one vote for their local candidate in their electorate (Candidate Vote) and a second vote for a party (Party Vote).

Both of the Party and Candidate votes can be explored using the summary dataset at the national-level. The number and type of seats can also be viewed using this dataset.

Party Vote

At a national level, the 120 seats are allocated to parties proportional to the number of votes each party received from the Party Vote. The number of electorates won are then subtracted from this number and the remaining seats are distributed to the party’s allocation (top-up).

The order in which seats are allocated are determined using the Sainte-Laguë formula:

\[ quotient = \frac{V}{2s + 1} \]

where:

  • \(V\) is the total number of votes that party received, and
  • \(s\) is the number of seats that have been allocated so far to that party.

A detailed explanation of the allocation process can be found in the Seat Allocation Explained article. For electorate-level Party Vote data, view the party_votes dataset.

Candidate Vote

The FPTP results can be accessed through the candidate_votes dataset at the electorate-level (NB. the candidate_votes dataset currently contains successful parties only, with unsuccessful parties being grouped as ‘Other’). The type of electorate (Māori or General) can also be identified using the add_type function.

In addition, the majority dataset lists the winner of each electorate (i.e., Candidate Vote), the majority, and the margin of victory/marginality. The majority is calculated using the following formula:

\[ Majority = candidate_{1} - candidate_{2} \]

where:

  • \(candidate_{1}\) is the number of votes that the first candidate received, and
  • \(candidate_{2}\) is the number of votes that the second candidate received.

The margin of victory, denoted by \(MoV\), has been calculated using the following formula:

\[ MoV = \frac{Majority}{n} \]

where:

  • \(n\) is the total valid votes cast in electorate for all candidates.

Overhang Seats

In circumstances where a party has won more electorates than it would be entitled to from the proportion of the Party Vote, those candidates retain their electorates and the total number of MPs elected to parliament increases. These are referred to as overhang seats. Overhang seats can be easily determined at each election. Details of how to determine overhang seats from the data can be found in the Summary article.

Eligibility

For parties to be eligible to have seats allocated to them, they either need to receive five per cent of the Party Vote or win at least one electorate. To look up whether or not a party was eligible in the election results, the Successful variable in the summary dataset contains this information.

Before MMP

In 1993, New Zealanders voted to change their voting system from FPTP to MMP. Data prior to 1996 (first general election in which MMP was used), is contained within the package. View the preMMP_results for the national-level popular vote and number of seats won by each party. Data goes back to 1890 and can be combined with the summary dataset for a comparison with the party vote. An example of this can be found in the Summary article.
